subtitle: chapter 44 with Mahatma Gandhi at Ward
ha
welcome to Ward ha Mahadev Dessie
secretary to Mahatma Gandhi greeted miss
blech mr. right and myself with these
cordial words in the gift of wreath of
Kadare homespun cotton our little group
had just dismounted at the ward house
station on an early morning August
gladly the dust and heat of the Train
consigning our luggage to a bullock cart
we entered an open motor car with mr.
Dessy and his companion Baba Saheb
Deshmukh and dr. ping go a short drive
over the muddy roads brought us to Magan
Vaati
the ashram of India's political Saint
mr. desi led us at once to the writing
room where cross-legged sat Mahatma
Gandhi Penh in one hand and a scrap of
paper and the other on his face a vast
winning warm-hearted smile welcomed he
scribbled in Hindi it was Monday his
weekly day of silence though this was
our first meeting we beamed on each
other affectionately in 1925 Mahatma
Gandhi had honored Durant's school by a
visit and inscribed in its guestbook a
gracious tribute the teeny 100-pound
Saint radiated physical mental and
spiritual health
his soft brown eyes shone with
intelligence sincerity and
discrimination this statement has
matched his wits and emerged the victor
in a thousand legal social and political
battles no other leader in the world has
attained the secure niche in the hearts
of his people that Gandhi occupied for
India's unlettered Millions
their spontaneous tribute is his famous
title Mahatma great soul for them alone
Gandhi confines the tire to the widely
cartoon loincloth symbol of his oneness
with the downtrodden masses who can
afford no more the ashram residents are
wholly at your disposal please call in
him for any service with characters to
courtesy the Mahatma handed me his
hastily written note as mr. Dessy letter
party for the writing room toward the
guesthouse
our guide led us through orchids of
flowering fields to a tile-roofed
building with lattice windows a front
yard well 25 feet across was used missy
desi said for water in stock nearby
stood revolving cement wheel for
threshing rice each of our small
bedrooms proved to contain only the
irreducible minimum a bed hand made of
rope the whitewash kitchen boasted a
faucet one corner and a fire pot for
cooking and another simple Arcadian
sounds reached our ears the cries of
crows and sparrows the lowing of the
cattle and the rap of chisels being used
to chip stones observing mr. Wright's
travel diary
mr. desi opened a page and wrote on it a
list of satyagraha vows taken by the
Mahatma's strict followers satra Gras
fees non-violence truth non-stealing
celibacy non-possession body labor
control of the palate fearlessness equal
respect for all religions Swadeshi use
of home manufacturer's freedom from
untouchability these eleven should be
observed as vows in the spirit of
humility
Gandhi himself signed this page in the
following day giving the date also
August 27 1935 two hours after our
arrival my companions and I were
summoned to lunch the Mahatma was
already seated on the arcade of the
ashram porch across the courtyard from a
study about 25 barefooted SATA gravies
were squatting before brass cups and
plates a community chorus of prayers
then a meal served from large brass pots
containing chapattis whole wheat
unleavened bread sprinkled with ghee
tall sari boiled and diced vegetables
and a lemon jam the Mahatma ate chapatis
boiled beets some raw vegetables and
oranges on the side of his plate was a
large lump of very bitter neem leaves a
notable blood cleanser with his spoon
separated a portion and placed it on my
plate I bolted it down with water
remembering childhood days when mother
had forced me to swallow two
disagreeable dose Gandhi however bit by
bit was eaten the neem paste with as
much relish as if it had been a
delicious sweet meat in this trifling
incident I noted the Mahatma's ability
to detach his mind from the senses at
will I recall the famous appendectomy
performed on him some years ago refusing
anaesthetic the Saint had chatted
cheerfully with the disciples throughout
the operation his infectious smile
revealing his unawareness of pain the
afternoon brought an opportunity for a
chat with Gandhi's not a disciple
daughter of an English Admiral miss
Madeline Slade now called marabi her
strong calm face lit with enthusiasm as
she told me in flawless Hindi of her
daily activities rural reconstruction
work is rewarding a group of us go every
morning at 5 o'clock to serve the nearby
villagers and teach them simple hygiene
we make it a point to clean their
latrines in their mud thatched huts the
villagers are illiterate they cannot be
educated except by example she laughed
gaily I looked in admiration at this
highborn English woman whose true
Christian humility enables her to do the
scavenging work usually performed only
by the untouchables I came to India in
1925 she told me in this land I feel
that I have come back home
now I would never be willing to return
to my old life mild interest we
discussed America for a while
I have always pleased in a man she said
to see the deep interest in spiritual
subjects exhibited by the many Americans
who visit India miyabi's hands were soon
busy at the Charaka spinning wheel
omnipresent in all the ashram rooms and
indeed due to the Mahatma omnipresent
throughout rural India Gandhi has sound
economic and cultural reasons for
encouraging the revival of cottage
industries but he does not counsel a
fanatical repudiation of all modern
progress machinery trains automobiles
raph have played important parts in his
own colossal life 50 years of public
service in prison and out wrestling
daily with practical details and harsh
realities in the political world have
only increased his balance
open-mindedness sanity and humorous
appreciation of the quaint human
spectacle
our trio enjoyed a six o'clock supper as
guests of Baba Shem Deshmukh the 7:00
p.m. prayer hour found us back at the
Magan voddy ashram climbing to the roof
where 30 South agrees were grouped in a
semicircle around Gandhi he was
squatting on a straw mat an ancient
pocket watch propped up before him the
fading Sun cast a last gleam of the
palms and Banyan's the hum of night and
crickets had started the atmosphere was
serenity itself I was in rapture a
solemn chant led by mr. Dessy with
response from the group then a Gita
reading the Mahatma motioned me to give
the concluding prayer such divine unison
of thought and aspiration a memory
forever
the Warthog rooftop meditation under the
early stars punctually at eight o'clock
Gandhi ended his silence the Herculean
Labor's of his life required him to
apportion his time on noodly welcome
Swamiji the Mahatma is greeting this
time was not via paper we had just
descended from the roof to his writing
room simply furnished with square mats
no chairs a low desk with books papers
and a few ordinary pens not fountain
pens a nondescript clock ticked in the
corner an all-pervasive aura of peace
and devotion
Gandhi was bestowing one of his
captivating cavernous almost toothless
smiles years ago he explained I started
my weekly observance of a day of silence
as a means for gaining time to look
after my correspondence but now these 24
hours have become a vital spiritual need
a periodical degree of silence is not a
torture but a blessing I agreed
wholeheartedly the Mahatma questioned me
about American Europe we discussed India
and world conditions Mahadev Gandhi said
as mr. Desai entered the room please
make arrangements at Town Hall for
Swamiji to meet there on a yoga tomorrow
night as I was bidding the Mahatma
goodnight he consider Li handed me a
bottle of citronella oil the ward ha
mosquitoes don't know a thing about him
Swami J he said laughingly the following
morning our little group breakfasted
early on a tasty wheat porridge with
molasses and milk at 10:30 we are called
to the ashram porch for lunch with
Gandhi and the statue cries today the
menu included brown rice a new selection
of vegetables and cardamom seeds noon
found me strolling about the ashram
grounds on the grazing land of a few
imperturbable crowds the production of
cows is a passion of Gandhi the cow to
me means the entire subhuman world
extending man sympathies beyond his own
species the Mahatma has explained man
through the cows and joined to realize
his indentity
with all that lives why the ancient
Rishi's selected the cow for apophysis
as obvious to me the cow of India was
the best comparison
she was the giver of Plenty not only did
you give milk but she also made
agriculture possible the call is a poem
of pity one reads pity in the gentle
animal she is the second mother to
millions of mankind
protection of the cow means protection
of the whole dumb creation of God the
appeal of the lower order of creation is
all the more forceful because it is
speechless three daily rituals are
enjoyed on the Orthodox Hindu one is
Bhutto Jana an offering of food to the
animal kingdom this ceremony symbolizes
man realization of his obligation to
less evolved forms of creation
instinctively tied to bodily
identification x' which also corrode
human life but lacking in that quality
of liberating reason which is peculiar
humanity buta jyotsna thus reinforces
man's readiness to succour the weak as
he in turn is conferred by countless
solicitudes of higher unseen being man
is also under bond for rejuvenating
gifts of nature protocol and earth sea
and sky the evolutionary barrier of an
communicability among nature animals man
and master Allah angels is thus overcome
by offices of silent love the other to
daily Yanis are Pitre and nari Pitre
yojna is an offering of oblations to
ancestors as a symbol of man's
acknowledgment of his debt to the past
essence of whose wisdom illumines
humanity today nari yojna is an offering
of food to strange the poor symbol of
the present responsibilities of man his
duties to contemporaries in the early
afternoon I fulfilled a neighborly near
younga by a visit to Gandhi's ashram for
little girls mr. right accompanied me on
the 10-minute Drive tiny young flower
like faces atop belongs thumbed colorful
saris at the end of a brief talk in
Hindi which I was giving out door the
sky's on lucent a sudden downpour
laughing mr. right and I climbed aboard
the board and sped back to my Avadi
amidst sheets of driving silver such
tropical intensity and splash
re-entering the guest house I was struck
anew by the stark simplicity and
evidence of self-sacrifice which are
everywhere present the Gandhi valve
non-possession came early in his married
life renouncing an extensive legal
practice which had been yielding him an
annual income of more than $20,000 the
Mahatma dispersed all is wealth to the
poor Sri Yukteswar used to poke gentle
fun at the calmly inadequate conceptions
of renunciation a beggar cannot renounce
wealth Master would say if a man laments
my business has failed my wife has left
me I will renounce all and enter modest
- what worldly sacrifice is he referring
he did not renounce wealth and love they
renounced him Saints like Gandhi on the
other hand have made not only tangible
material sacrifices but also the more
difficult renunciation of selfish motive
and pride of gold merging their inmost
being into the stream of humanity as a
whole
the Mahatma's remarkable wife cut
Surabhi did not object when he failed to
set aside any part of his wealth for the
use of herself and their children
married in early youth Gandhi and his
wife took the vow of celibacy after the
birth of several sons a tranquil heroine
in the intense drama that has been their
life together
Katsuragi has followed her husband to
prison shared his three week fast and
fully borne her share of his endless
responsibilities she is paid Gandhi the
following tribute I thank you for having
had the privilege of being your lifelong
companion and help me I thank you for
the most perfect marriage in the world
based on bra mature ayah self-control
and not on sex I thank you for having
consider me your equal in your life work
in India I thank you for not being one
of those husbands who spend their time
in gambling racing women wine and song
tiring of their wives and children has a
little boy quickly tires of his
childhood toys how thankful I am that
you are not one of those husband's who
devote their time to growing rich on the
exploitation of the labors of others how
thankful I am that you put God and
country before bribes and that you had
the courage of your convictions in a
complete and implicit faith in God how
thankful I am for a husband that put God
in his country before me I am grateful
to you for your tolerance of me and my
shortcomings of youth when I grumble and
rebelled against the change you made in
our mode of living from so much to so
little as a young child I lived in your
parents home your mother was a great and
good woman she trained me taught me how
to be a brave courageous wife and how to
keep the love and respect averse
my future husband as the years passed
and you became India's most beloved
leader I had none of the fears that
beset the wife who may be cast aside
when her husband has climbed the ladder
of success as so often happens in other
countries
I knew that death would still find his
husband and wife for years cuts Robby
performed the duties of treasurer of the
public funds which he idolized Mahatma
is able to raise by the millions
there are many humorous stories in
Indian homes to the effect that husbands
are nervous about their wives wearing
any jewelry to a Gandhi meeting the
Mahatma's magical tongue pleading for
the downtrodden charms the gold
bracelets and diamond necklaces right
off the arms and necks of the wealthy
into the collection basket
one day the public treasure cuts Robby
could not account for disbursement of 4
rupees
a Gandhi duly published an auditing in
which he and extra bleep oint ax doubt
his wife's four rupee discrepancy I had
often told a story before classes of my
American students one evening a woman in
the hall had given an outraged gasp
Mahatma or no Mahatma she had cried if
he were my husband
I would given him a black eye for such
an unnecessary public insult after some
good humoured bantered had passed
between us on the subject of American
wives and Hindu wives I had gone on to a
fuller explanation mrs. Gandhi considers
the Mahatma not as her husband but as
her guru one who has the right to
discipline her for even insignificant
errors I had pointed out sometime after
kotsaba had been publicly rebuked Gandhi
was sentenced to prison on a political
charge as he was calmly bidding farewell
to his wife she fell at his feet master
she said humbly if I have ever offended
you please forgive me at three o'clock
that afternoon and worte I we took
myself by previous appointment to the
writing room of the saint who had been
able to make an unflinching disciple out
of his own wife rare miracle Gandhi
looked up with his unforgettable smile
Mahatma ji said as I squatted beside him
on on cushion mat please tell me of your
definition of ahimsa the avoidance of
harm to any living creature in thought
or deed beautiful idea but the world
will always ask may one not kill a Cobra
protector child or oneself I could not
kill a Cobra without violating two of my
vows fearlessness and non killing I
would rather try inwardly to calm the
snake by vibrations of love I cannot
possibly lower my standards to suit my
circumstances with this amazing candor
Gandhi added I must confess that I could
not carry on this conversation where I
faced by a Cobra I remarked on several
very recent Western books on diet which
lay in his desk
yes diet is important in satara movement
as everyone else he said with a chuckle
because I advocate complete continents
for Saturdays I am always trying to find
out the best diet for the celibate one
must conquer the palate before he can
control the procreative instinct
semi-starvation or unbalanced diets are
not the answer after overcoming the
inward greed for food a Saturday I must
continue to follow a rational vegetarian
diet with all necessary vitamins
minerals calories and so forth by inward
and outward wisdom in regard to eating
the SATA grass sexual fluidity ly turn
into vital energy for the whole body the
Mahatma and I compared our knowledge of
good meat substitutes the avocado is
excellent I said there are numerous
avocado groves near my Center in
California
Gandhi's face lit with interest I wonder
if they would grow in Ward ha The
Saturdays would appreciate a new food I
will be sure to send some avocado plants
from Los Angeles to Warthog and added
eggs are a high-protein food are they
forbidden to such a grave not
unfertilized eggs the Mahatma laughed
reminiscently for years I would not
countenance their use even now I
do not eat them one of my
daughters-in-law was once died of
malnutrition her doctor insisted on eggs
I would not agree and advised him to
give her some eggs substitute Gandhiji
the doctor said unfertilized eggs
contain no life sperm no killing is
involved
I then gladly gave permission for my
daughter-in-law to eat eggs she soon
restored to health on the previous night
Gandhi had expressed the wish to receive
the Kriya yoga of Larry Masha I was
touched by the Mahatma's open-mindedness
and spirit of inquiry he is childlike in
his divine request revealing the pure
receptivity which Jesus prays and
children of such is the kingdom of
heaven the hour for my promised
instruction had arrived several
subtleties now entered the room
mr. desi dr. Pingel and others who
desired the Kriya technique I first
taught the little class the physical you
gotta exercises the body is visualized
is divided into 20 parts the wheel
directs energy and turn to each section
soon everyone was vibrating before me
like a human motor it was easy to
observe the rippling effect on Gandhi's
20 body parts at all times completely
exposed to view though very thin he is
not unpleasantly so the skin of his body
is smooth and unwrinkled later I
initiated the group into the liberating
technique of Kriya yoga the Mahatma had
reverently studied all world religions
that Jain scriptures the biblical New
Testament and the sociological writings
of Tolstoy are the three main sources of
Gandhi's nonviolent convictions he has
stated his Creed Olas I believe the
Bible the Koran and the Zen Avesta to be
as divinely inspired as the Vedas I
believe in the institution of gurus but
in this age millions must go without a
guru because it is a rare thing to find
a combination of perfect purity and
perfect learning but one not need to
spare or ever knowing the truth of one's
religion because the fundamentals of
to ISM as of every great religion are
unchangeable and easily understood I
believe like every Hindu in God and his
oneness in rebirth and salvation I can
no more describe my feelings for
Hinduism than for my own wife she moves
me as no other woman in the world can
not that she has no fault I daresay she
has many more than I see myself but the
feelings of an indissoluble bond is
there even so I feel foreign about
Hinduism with all its faults and
limitations
nothing delights me so much as the music
of the Gita or the Ramayana by tall
cities when I fancied I was taking my
last breath the Gita was my solace
Hinduism is not an exclusive religion in
it there is room for worship of all the
prophets of the world it is not a
missionary religion in the ordinary
sense of the term it has no doubt
absorbed many tribes in its fold but
this absorption has been an evolutionary
imperceptible character Hinduism tells
each man to worship God according to his
own faith or Dharma and so lives at
peace with all religions of Christ
Gandhi had written I am sure that if you
were living here now among men he would
bless the lives of many who perhaps have
never heard his name just it is written
not everyone that saith unto me Lord
Lord but he that doeth the will of my
father in the lesson of his own life
Jesus gave humanity the Magnificent
purpose and the single objective toward
which we all ought to aspire I believe
that he belongs not solely to
Christianity but the entire world to all
lands and races on my last evening in
war ha I addressed the meeting which one
called mr. desi in Town Hall the room
was thronged to the windowsills with
about 400 people assembled to hear the
talk on yoga I spoke first in Hindi then
in English our little group returned to
the ashram in time for good night
glimpse of Gandhi enfold in peace and
correspondence night was still lingering
when I rose at 5 a.m.
village life is already stirring first a
bullock cart by the ashram gates then a
peasant with his huge burden balanced
precariously in his head
after breakfast our trio sought out
Gandhi for farewell pronounce the saint
rises at 4 o'clock for his morning
prayer mahatma g-goodbye
i knelt to touch his feet india is safe
in your keeping years have rolled by
since the war da idol the earth oceans
and skies have darkened with a world of
war alone among great leaders Gandhi has
offered a practical nonviolent
alternative to armed might to redress
grievances and removing justices the
Mahatma is employed nonviolent means
which again and again have proved their
effectiveness he states his doctrines in
his words I have found that life
persists in the midst destruction
therefore there must be a higher law
than out of destruction only under that
law would well-ordered society be
intelligible and life worth living if
there is a law of life we must work it
out in daily existence wherever there
are Wars wherever we are confronted with
an opponent conquered by love I have
found the certain law of love has
answered in my own life as a law of
destruction is never done in India we
have had an ocular demonstration on the
operation of this law on the widest
scale possible I don't claim that
non-violence has penetrated the three
hundred and sixty million people in
India but I do claim it has penetrated
deeper than any other doctrine in an
incredibly short time it takes a fairly
strenuous course of training to attain a
mental state of non-violence it is a
discipline life like the life of a
soldier the perfect state has reached
only when the mind body and speech are
in proper coordination every problem
would lend itself to solution if we
determined make the law of truth and
non-violence the law of life just as a
scientist will work wonders out of
various applications of the laws of
nature a man who applies the laws of
love with scientific precision can work
greater wonders
non-violence is infinitely more
wonderful and subtle and forces of
nature
like for instance electricity the law of
love is a far greater science than any
modern science Consulting history one
may reasonably state that a problems of
mankind have not been solved by the use
of brute force world war 1 produced a
world chilling snowball of war kamar
that swelled in World War 2 only the
warmth of brotherhood can melt the
present colossal snowball of war comma
which may otherwise grow into World War
3 this unholy trinity will banish
forever the possibility of world war 4
by a finality of atomic bombs use of
jungle logic instead of human reason is

to a jungle if brothers not in life then
brothers in violent death warmed crime
never pays the billions of dollars that

nothingness would have been sufficient
to have been made a new world one almost
free from disease and completely free of

one broad land of peace of prosperity
and of widening knowledge the nonviolent

conscious let nations allow themselves
no longer with death but with life not

not with the Annihilator but with a
creator one should forgive under in the
injury says the Mahabharata it hath been

is holiness by forgiveness the
universe's held together forgiveness is
the might of the mighty forgiveness as
sacrifice forgiveness is quite of mine
forgiveness and gentleness are the
qualities of the self-possessed they
represent eternal virtue non-violence is

if loss of life becomes necessary in a

one should be prepared like Jesus to

eventually there will be less blood
spilt in the world epochs shall someday

ages Gandhi says rather than seek the

my nationalism includes the well-being
of the whole world I do not want my
India to rise on the ashes of other

I want India to be strong in order that
you can infect the other nations also

President Wilson mentioned his beautiful
14 points but said after all if this

we have our armaments to fall back upon
I want to reverse that position and say

any of us and that I never had anything

century colony in Pennsylvania there
were no 4ch
no soldiers no militia even no arms
amidst the savage frontier wars in the

the Quakers of Pennsylvania alone

I am fighting for nothing less in World

may say so in all humility to life
itself before the West dismisses
Gandhi's program as one of an practical
dreamer
let it first reflect on a definition of
such a guy by the master of Galilee you
have heard that it hath been said an eye
for an eye and a tooth for a tooth but I
say unto you that ye resist not evil but
whosoever shall smite thee on thy right
cheek turn to him the other also
Gandhi's epoch has extended with the
beautiful precision of cosmic timing
into a century already desolated and
devastated by two world wars a divine
handwriting appears on the granite wall
of his life a warning against the
further shedding of blood among brothers
Mahatma Gandhi visited my high school
with yoga training in Ranchi he
graciously wrote the above lines in the
raunchy guestbook the translation is
this institution has deeply impressed my
mind
I cherish high hopes at the school
encourage the further practical use of
the spinning wheel Mohandas Gandhi
September 17 1925 end of chapter
